text:
YVONNE NG: Well, good
afternoon, everyone. We're so glad you
could join us today

as we talk about the magic
behind OpenCourseWare. In some ways, what we do is
truly magical, because we

get to help produce the MIT
content thousands of people use every day.

And we're happy to share
it with you, share with you some of the inner
workings of what it takes to make OCW
courses and materials.

I'm Yvonne Ng, and I help run
the annual giving and donor relations for MIT Open Learning.

We're still celebrating
20 years of OpenCourseWare reaching more than 200 million
people around the world,

and we want to
recognize everyone who's used or supported the site. Because really, you've helped us
reach this incredible success.

So thank you for that. A few housekeeping notes. Today's discussion will
be recorded and shared

with our community. Your participation today
indicates your willingness to share your
questions and comments

in making this recording. If you would like captions,
please click on the CC button

at the bottom of your screen. To ask a question, please
type it in the Q&A box.

Just to let you know, we
received over 100 questions and comments to date. So we'll plan to try to
answer some of those in a blog

or on our social media channels,
as well as this session. And so today I'm super happy to
have three wonderful OCW team

members who all know the ins
and outs of OpenCourseWare. So would you amazing people
briefly introduce yourself,

and perhaps share a fun fact? And we'll start
with you, Sharon.

SHARON LIN: Hi, everyone. So my name is Sharon Lin. I'm a digital publication
specialist at OpenCourseWare.

I also manage the
mirror site program. When not at work, I'm
a freelance journalist

covering for the Taiwanese
American Society. I cover topics and events
from education all the way
to food and entertainment. YVONNE NG: That's amazing.

I didn't even know that! That's awesome, Sharon. Shiba, did you want
to introduce yourself?

SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER:
Hi, everyone. My name is Shiba Nemat-Nasser. I've been at MIT
for a long time.

I first worked at
the business school, and I've been at OCW for
a number of years now.

I'm from originally
from California. I came here for grad school. And I'm also a
professional singer.

I specialize in opera
and early music, so that's my other career.

YVONNE NG: I love that. That's so fascinating. Brett, did you want to go
ahead and introduce yourself?

BRETT PACI: Sure. I'm Brett Paci, and I handle
all things audio video for OCW,

with an awesome video team
that we have here on staff. I've been at OCW almost
since the beginning.

What I do when I'm
not working here is I also have another
podcast, in addition to working on the OCW podcast,
Chalk Radio, called the Skywok.

Sky as in sky, wok as in
the thing you cook in, spelled W-O-K. A
Star Wars podcast,

because the world doesn't
have enough of those. And yeah, that's about it.
YVONNE NG: That's so great. I love your podcast, by the way. I get my fix, my Star Wars fix.

Anyway, thank you all for
introducing yourselves. I want to share
with the audience that these folks are completely
lovely, and wonderful to work

with. And I feel truly lucky to be
able to be their colleague. So for fun, and before
we dive into the magic,

we're going to test you, our
friends joining us today, on your knowledge
of OpenCourseWare.

We're going to launch a poll. And the question is, there are
a plethora of courses, lots

and lots of courses on OCW. How many courses do you
think are available on OCW?

And we're just going
to give another 10 seconds before we close.

OK, and the results? 53% of you said more
than 2,500 courses,

and you guys are right! That's right, we cover just
about everything taught at MIT,

at both the undergraduate
and graduate levels. And we've been doing this,
of course, for 20 years.

So the very first question
to the panel is this.

With such a massive
library of courses that span the entire
MIT curriculum,

how does an OCW
course come together? How do you choose
which topic to publish?

And maybe we'll
start with Shiba. SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER: Sure. Let me give you a general
overview of our timeline,

and the publication
cycle, and what we cover in the curriculum.

So we have a pretty
small publication team. Actually it's only
about nine people, and overall OCW is
only about 19 people.

And we divide all the
departments across MIT

up between everyone, and
into two micro teams. So that's kind of
how we organize.

And what's covered in
the curriculum, looking back at the original impetus
20 years ago, at the founders,

basically they wanted to
publish all the course materials online, and make them
widely available to everyone.

So that means all. And you might be surprised. A lot of people are
surprised that MIT

has majors not just in
STEM, not just in math, and engineering, and
physics, and science.

But you can get a degree at MIT
in art, literature, writing,

history, music, theater,
several different languages,

humanities, philosophy, and even
ancient and medieval studies.

So you can definitely have
a different kind of degree

from MIT as an undergrad. So we do our best
to represent what's

offered across the
entire MIT curriculum. And Brett will talk a little
more about this later.

But some types of
courses are more suitable as an online
course, and what can

be communicated on this medium. But I would say
that we try our best

to continue to cover the
entire curriculum across MIT.

And maybe Sharon, can you pick
up a little bit more about how we choose classes?

SHARON LIN: Sure. So we have a holistic
process to determine which courses to publish.

First, we have a Faculty
Advisory Committee which provides guidance of
publishing specialty courses

that are MIT-unique. And our director will reach
out to each department,

and organize a
departmental meeting with the Department Head, along
with our publication managers

and digital publication
specialists. We will identify
priority courses

to publish for the cycle. And on top of that, we also
receive faculty's request

to publish their courses. And also, in
addition to that, OCW

has several course
lists, each of which

represents a hot topic. And we constantly
create new ones

based on the feedback
from our users. So that's my comment.

YVONNE NG: And Brett, can
you talk a little bit more about how we manage
user feedback?

And if there is any influence at
all in our publication topics?

BRETT PACI: Yeah,
when it comes to video it's sort of a microcosm of
what Sharon and Shiba just described.

It depends on
faculty availability, what do we already have
in the OCW catalog,

even when it comes to video. But also we do take
people's feedback. So for example, today
somebody wrote in a question

about organic chemistry. And that is the sort of
thing that I will pass along to the rest of the team,
to the team that works

with the different departments. To see if there is
something that we might be able to recruit,
to publish as an OCW course,

or to film the class so that
we can put the lectures up on YouTube. And on YouTube we get
a lot of feedback.

So we have a great
feedback team, including Shiba
and my colleague,

Jason, who are constantly
reviewing YouTube comments. And we do take those seriously. And when we see that
people are requesting

the same thing a lot,
then we will look into it, and we'll try to follow
up with the department,

or with faculty members that
might be teaching that course, and see if we can
get that one set up.
To film it and to put it on OCW. YVONNE NG: Yeah, I love that.

We really do care about the
people that use our resources. And so we're always
listening to them.

And wherever they show up,
whether it's on our website through a feedback email, or
on our social media channels,

or on our YouTube channel. So you guys are
working with some

of the most accomplished and
prestigious faculty in higher education.

What is it like to
collaborate with them? And do you have any
good stories to share.

We'll start with you, Brett. BRETT PACI: Yeah, I have
a lot of good stories.

And it's always fun,
working with MIT faculty. I get to work with anybody
who is a guest on our podcast,

Chalk Radio, or
anybody who wants to have their class
filmed to be put on OCW.

This semester I
have the privilege of working with Esther Duflo. I won't say exactly
what until later.

But I have also had the
privilege-- somebody that we're constantly
getting feedback at OCW,

glowing feedback
about Gil Strang, who is so beloved at MIT. And actually his content
predates OpenCourseWare.

And I've had several
opportunities to work with him. And he's always wanting
to film his courses

and share his materials
with the world. The cool thing is the
MIT faculty are so nice.

People say, never
meet your heroes, but everybody should
meet Gil Strang, because he's genuinely one of
the nicest people I've ever

met. And it's always a
pleasure to work with him. And the funny thing-- something I find
inspirational about Gil

is that Gil is now 86
years old and still going strong, still teaching.

I think the last
time I had the chance to meet with him for something
that we were filming, one of his courses,
me and Elizabeth,

one of our colleagues at OCW who
works with the math department. We got to Gil's office,
and one of the first things

he asked us was, did I
tell you about my new book? And Elizabeth and I
looked at each other

like, we know he just wrote one,
is he talking about that one, or is it another one?

And it turns out it was
actually another one that was newer than the one
that we had just found out about not that long ago.

And I think that was for the
course that he's teaching. And this is what's so
inspirational, too, and you can hear this on
the Chalk Radio podcast,

the episode that
features Gil Strang, is he's still teaching new things.

So the last course
that we filmed he was talking about
machine learning. And in his interview
on talk Chalk Radio,

when Sarah, who
hosts Chalk Radio, asked him, what is it like to
teach a new topic that you've

never taught before, that's
a relatively new field? And just immediately he
said, oh, it's exciting.

So to me, just seeing
that he's completely fearless in teaching
new content, learning new things still.

We're not all Gil Strang,
but we can all keep learning. So yeah, it's a lot
of fun, and we have

a lot of great experiences. We feel very fortunate
to do what we do. SHARON LIN: OK, great.

So when I worked
with MIT faculty, I would see the
shine in their eyes

when they talked
about their OCW story. So one time I was working with
emeritus professor Shigeru

Miyagawa, who is a
dear friend of OCW. He was telling us about the
story of the founding of OCW,

back in 2000, way, way before
I joined the team in 2012. And hearing him telling us about
the commitment to teaching,

and the enthusiasm of sharing
their teaching materials with the world that is
stated in the MIT mission,

to disseminate knowledge,
just resonated in my heart. I feel so proud and humbled
at the same time when I'm

working with our instructors. I feel very proud to be part
of this vision of a commitment

to teaching, this
mission of sharing knowledge with the
world, with everyone,

and this great OER movement. But I also feel very
humbled at the same time,

because it is and it has
to be a collective effort.

This cannot be done
by any single person. We need our MIT faculty
researchers, the publication

team, our users, our donors
to all be part of this effort.

So that's my sharing. SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER: So I'll just say
one more thing about that.

I wanted to say that we
have such a wide range

of individual personalities
of these amazing faculty that we have at MIT. And working with them
is just so much fun.

I absolutely love
working with MIT faculty.

And one of the things
that comes through, and I would say comes through
each and every one of them,

is their dedication to
teaching and their inspiration

to make their teaching
materials available through OCW to the world.

Because they really
support OCW in this,

because they know that
being able to go through OCW

is a much wider reach,
something that they simply can't do just by teaching
individual students
in the classroom. So I just wanted to add that.

BRETT PACI: Yvonne is having
a technical difficulty. It's Zoom!

All right. Maybe I should
kick off the poll. The poll says, there it is.

Video lectures are some of the
most popular resources on OCW. How many OCW courses
contain video?

I feel like we always want to
take the "over" on these polls. Yes.

That's right. So over, wow, I can't
read that from here.

But over 100 was the
correct answer for that one. Looks like 78% of you
got that one right.

So you just keep
guessing the over.

Right, so Yvonne is still
having technical difficulties. So I guess I can
just jump in here and lead us to our next topic.

We know from feedback that
we get from our learners that the most requested
resource is video,

and video is a powerful
tool for learning. And people often ask, why aren't
all the courses video-based?

And how do you choose which
courses will have video? And I touched on this
a little bit earlier.

A lot of it is sort
of self-selective, the faculty that are
available, the courses and the topics that
maybe haven't been

covered as much on OCW yet. So we try to target those. But some of it is
related to resources.

Of course, MIT puts in a lot of
money to even make OCW happen, and to be able to
share this content

with the world for free. But donations help, as well. So we appreciate everybody
who gives to OCW.

And that does give us
greater flexibility to take on more course
videos and share

and share that stuff with the world. I will also add
to that that one of the things that we've
tried to do over the last,

say, five years or so, I'd
say in the early days of OCW, even with just the
general course content,

we targeted the materials
and the courses that really lent themselves to a website.

That had good
tangible materials, that were easy to make
available online, that people could really learn from online.

And something we've tried to
do over the last several years is target some of the things
that are even more difficult. So one of the
great things at OCW

is the OCW Educator initiative
led by Sarah Hansen, who does an amazing job with that.

And that's allowed us to share
not just the course content,

but also how the
courses are taught. And it's also allowed us to
showcase some of the things, even in video, that
aren't typically that

easy to capture with video. So one of the things at
MIT that is so important are recitation sessions.

And so going back
several years, we were able to work with
Steve Hall in the AeroAstro department to capture.

That's just one
example of something we were able to capture. That's a little
different than what you see in a typical
classroom, where

you have the
session starting off with a problem on the board. And then the
instructor going around

and helping different groups
of students to problem solve. And so we've really been
trying to do some of that.

We've also gotten to do that
in a recent course that we published, 5.310, which
is a chemistry course.

Being able to film
some things in the lab, and filming a field trip
to the Charles River, which

we hope to be able to share
with everyone in the world at some point in the future. So again, there are
restrictions to what we can do,

resources being one of them. But I feel very
fortunate that we've been able to capture
as much as we can,

and even some of
the difficult stuff to capture, and share
that with the world.

YVONNE NG: That's wonderful,
thank you for answering that, Brett. I think when we were looking at
recent analytics for the videos

on our YouTube channel, we
know that our videos have been viewed over 13 million times.

That's incredible. So now we are ready to
take some questions.

We have gotten, as
I mentioned before, over 100 questions and
comments from folks that

have registered for this event. But one question from Aditya,
and a few other people

have asked this, as well, is
whether or not OCW would ever

entertain the idea of providing
some sort of credential, a badge, a certificate for
completing an OCW course.

He says ever since
the pandemic hit, it seems to have become an
important thing to possess.

So happy to throw it to
anybody on the panel. Shiba, did you want to take
a crack at that question?

SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER: Sure. Yeah. So this is a question
that we get a lot. As Brett mentioned, I'm
also on the feedback team,

I'm the feedback lead, actually. So currently OCW
is not set up to do

any kind of
tracking, or creating a login, or anything like that.

So we don't actually
have any way to know whether someone's
completed any course materials.

However, Open Learning has
the Open Learning Library

right now, which you
can track your progress. They don't offer
certificates, per se,

but this is a place where-- I mean, I can't say whether or
not we're entertaining this.

I have no idea what
they're thinking about.

That has generally
been something that's been with the MOOCs
and MITx, and some of that

is changing now. So there may be
new possibilities.

But OpenCourseWare
is really more of a library and an archive. And we're just not
set up currently

to do anything like that. Although there's
many cases of people

who take OpenCourseWare
materials and use them in a high
school student situation,

independent study, maybe
in a community college where they don't have a specific
higher course that we do offer

on OpenCourseWare, and use those
materials to grant a student

credential in that course. But we don't really have
any involvement in that. But we just know that
that does happen.

So unfortunately, currently
no plans for certification.

So we can't make any
promises about that. But who knows the future?

It's definitely something,
as the user points out,

it's something that is
considered important. And MIT has some
other new things,

like MicroMasters and so on,
that do offer certification.

So you can look
into those, as well. YVONNE NG: Thanks for
answering that, Shiba.

The next question
comes from Mohammed. He asks, can we broadcast
live classes from MIT

to universities
around the world? And I'll ask either Sharon
or Brett to take that answer.

BRETT PACI: OK, I
can take that one.

Yeah, that's not something
that we really currently do. MIT does have a sort of
joint classes that it offers.

The MIT-Singapore
Alliance I think was one, that some
of our colleagues who now work with OCW had
worked on in the past.

As far as OCW actually
sharing out live courses, it's not something that
we really do at all. We're doing something pretty
close this semester, actually.

It's an interesting question. The course is
course number 21, I

think it's 21AS01, which
is about reparations

and colonialization. And that's a course where we're
really trying something new, where we're publishing the
videos before the class,

and then using the comments
from the comment section to kick off the discussion
that happens in class.

So really, the videos are
being shared with our YouTube subscribers, and then
the discussion that takes

place there is
actually influencing the on-campus experience. So as far as live stuff,
a livestream like this

is about as live as we get. But I think that's
something that we could see more of in
the future, if we feel

like there's a need for it. One of the challenges
in that, of course, is that one of the
big things that we

have to take into account at
OCW is intellectual property. So if there's any sort of
third-party materials involved

that are fine to use in
the class, on-campus, those have to be worked through
to make sure we have permission

to share them out to
the world, the way we do with all of our materials. So that's also an
important factor.

YVONNE NG: Thanks, Brett. The next question
comes from Tom, who asks, what do
we see as the vision

for remote, rural schools
within our Navajo Nation where I teach?

And I think Sharon might be
able to answer to this question. SHARON LIN: Yes,
I'd be happy to.

So OCW actually has
a mirror site program that we would send
a hard drive that

contains a hard copy of
our current live site. And we use this, it would be
great for internet-limited

learning communities. So for Tom, it'd be great
to share the words for us,

share with your
learning communities, share with your circles, and
then help them connect with us.

And we'd be happy to
establish more collaborations with different learning
communities that have

this need around the world. YVONNE NG: Thank you. And I would encourage you,
Tom, to shoot us an email,

ocw@mit.edu, and let us
know where you're based, so that we can connect.

And see if we can get
a hard drive to you, so that you can share
with your community.

The next question
comes from Mussie. How significant
is the difference

between an OCW course and
one offered on campus?

I'll shoot out to
the panel, whoever wants to jump in and answer.

SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER: Brett,
did you want to answer that? BRETT PACI: Yeah,
I could answer it.

I mean, I can answer it
in terms of video courses. Typically what we do
is we film classes that

are happening on campus. So what you're
getting in the video is pretty much everything
that you would get. So not much different, I
guess, would be the answer

when it comes to video. Really the only things that
get cut out of our videos are any personal information,
like a faculty's contact

information, and
things like that. Technical problems that
happen in the class,

if the projector
is not working we save you the trouble of
sitting through that. But really most of what's
happening on campus

is what you see in the videos. SHARON LIN: And now add
on to Brett's comment,

I think as a
publication specialist, we try our best to preserve the
authenticity of the teaching

materials. So from time to time we do have
to do some treatment because

of the IP reason. We have to make sure
that the materials we're sharing actually are
compatible to our CC license.

I think that's usually the
major source of editing. Other than that we can say that
it's pretty authentic to what
was offered on campus.

YVONNE NG: Yeah, and
do you guys still try to recreate images when
there are copyright issues?

Is that something that
you guys still try to do? BRETT PACI: Yes.

Yeah, I was going to say, we've
done that for entire courses at times when it was necessary. So that's another thing
that's really cool,

is occasionally we've been
able to commission new images to serve the same
purpose as the images

that we couldn't use due
to copyright reasons. And sometimes, just
a little shout out to our amazing team of editors,
Jason, Maureen, and Elaine,

and Andrea, who do
amazing work, sometimes they even recreate,
when you have a slide,

we're filming the slides that
are being shown in the class. Sometimes there's a laser
pointer or something

else that doesn't really
show up well in the video, so sometimes they even
painstakingly go through

and recreate the movement of
the cursor or the pointer, so that the end user can see
exactly what the instructor was

pointing at. YVONNE NG: So Bruce asked,
how much feedback do you get,

and what do you do with it? I think Shiba would be a good
point person for this question.

SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER: Yeah, sure. So we do get a lot of feedback. So we have about
2 million people

visiting the
website every month, and 4 million people
on YouTube per month.

So we definitely get a lot,
and a wide variety of feedback.

So we try to answer
all the questions that come in through the web form.

And Jason, who's
on the video team

that Brett mentioned
before, is also. And he and I answer feedback
questions on YouTube, as well.

So we really do have
a wonderful user base. So most of the
feedback that we get

is very thoughtful
and constructive. And as Brett said, we do
take everyone's suggestions

and requests seriously. So if someone's asking
for a specific course,

or a feature request,
we'll log that and we'll-- Oftentimes, similar
things will bubble up,

especially over the years. And our users are also
really helpful if something

goes wrong. If something breaks, they'll
send us messages and let us know, which is great.

But we really do consider the
user feedback, and especially

any kind of requests for
features, things that have bubbled up over the years.

In our creating the
next generation of OCW, we take these seriously,
and we take them

all into consideration. So there's a lot of great
ideas that people have,

and the user base are the
people who use the materials.

So we definitely want
to hear from you. We want to know how you use
it, and how to make it better.

So [DOORBELL RINGS] YVONNE NG: Thank you. So we actually have
another video question

towards lectures
for which knowledge stays relevant longer, like
math, physics, chemistry,

electrical
engineering, et cetera, versus fast-moving fields,
for example, say, JavaScript.
Is this correct?

BRETT PACI: Wow. That's a really good question. I think I can honestly say that
that is not one of the biggest

factors that we take
into account when it comes to a video course. I think the bigger
question would be,

is it something
that we just filmed last semester, or last
year, and can that money be better spent on another
course that might not currently

exist on OCW? So it's not really something
that we think about too much. We do think about
that a lot when

it comes to refreshing
the content on OCW, because you're right. There are a lot of subjects
that pretty much stay

the same or pretty
close for a longer time, and other subjects
that are faster-moving.

So across the whole
publication, beyond just video, we do try to keep up
with that as best we can.

Usually with video, as
much video as we do have, it's still a small
percentage of what's

being taught overall at MIT. So that doesn't usually
factor in to the decisions

that we have to make there. YVONNE NG: Yeah. We have a question that
was submitted from Karen.

What is a typical timeline
for publishing a course? Do you ever work with
teams of faculty, and if so, how do
you facilitate?

Maybe Sharon, you could
take this question? SHARON LIN: Yes, I'm happy to.

I actually had a quick comment
to the previous question. Sometimes it is the instructor's
or the teaching team's wish

to capture or not to capture. I think sometimes usually it's
a reflection of the topic,

as well. Some topics just
evolve so quickly they don't even want
to capture the video.

They actually want it to
go out as fast as possible. Then we will make a very
quick executive decision,

and say, we'll just
publish the lecture slides so we can quickly move
on for the next edition.

And then I think
in a typical cycle for a course for
publication, if we

look at from the beginning
of the initial touchpoint, when we have the
first engagement

meeting, until the
course is published, usually we will get in
touch with the teaching team

before they start teaching it. So we can plan. If there's any filming
we can plan with Brett.

We can plan with
the teaching team how to optimize the
capturing or anything.

But usually the
publication will start as soon as the course is
finished for the semester.

So if I count that as the
beginning of the cycle, it's usually six months before
with the real publication

work, the author and
everything starts. But once we start, put this
in our publication queue,

I would say it depends on the
complexity of each course. Whether it's very rich
in content, whether it

needs a lot of video
editing, or content editing because of a lot of third-party
intellectual property objects.

So it could vary from two weeks
all the way to two months.

Sometimes we do have to reach
out to copyright holders to get their permission
in order to include

some images from a journal,
or another professor. So I would say,
average, probably just
about maybe a month. What do you think, Shiba?

SHIBA NEMAT-NASSER:
Yeah, well, I would say that it
really depends.

One to two months
for, I would say, your basic course that doesn't
have very many copyright

issues, no video. But you know, it
really depends on--

a content-rich
course that has lots of videos, that has
lecture notes that's full

of copyright clearance
type of things, that can take five or
six months, depending on

depending on how quickly we get
questions answered, how quickly permissions come in, and so on.

So it really varies. But we try to keep things
in our six-month cycle.

So we kind of
